keyTakeAways: The Louvre Museum in Paris suffered a major theft on Sunday, October 19, 2025, involving nine high-value artifacts from the Apollo Gallery, including a sapphire diadem, an emerald necklace, and several brooches linked to Napoleon and Empress Eugénie.
The heist lasted only seven minutes and targeted two high-security display cases, indicating a highly planned and sophisticated crime.
The emerald necklace was a wedding gift from Napoleon to Marie-Louise in 1810 and was purchased by the Louvre in 2004 for 3.7 million euros.
The sapphire diadem, possibly linked to Queen Marie Antoinette, includes 24 Ceylon sapphires and over 1,000 diamonds and was part of the Orléans family collection until 1985.
The reliquary brooch, crafted in 1855 for Empress Eugénie, contains the 17th and 18th Mazarin diamonds, originally given to Louis XIV by Cardinal Mazarin.
The diamond bow brooch originated from a 4,000-stone belt exhibited at the 1855 Universal Exhibition and was later transformed into a brooch by Eugénie.
The brooch was sold to Caroline Astor in 1887 and remained in the Astor family for over a century before being repurchased by the Louvre in 2008 for 6.72 million euros.
A pearl diadem made for Eugénie in 1853 contains 212 pearls and 1,998 diamonds and was part of the stolen items.
One of the stolen items, Eugénie’s crown, was recovered outside the museum but was damaged during the heist.
Art recovery expert Arthur Brand described the theft as a 'national disaster' for France, emphasizing the cultural significance and irreplaceable value of the artifacts.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In a major cultural heist on October 19, 2025, thieves broke into the Louvre Museum’s Apollo Gallery in Paris and stole nine high-value historical artifacts linked to Napoleon and Empress Eugénie. The items include a sapphire diadem and necklace from Napoleon’s second wife Marie-Louise, a reliquary brooch and diamond bow brooch crafted for Eugénie, and a pearl diadem. The theft, which lasted only seven minutes, targeted two high-security cases and was carried out by four individuals who fled on motorcycles. One item, Eugénie’s crown, was recovered outside the museum but was damaged. Art expert Arthur Brand described the event as a 'national disaster' for France, emphasizing the irreplaceable cultural and historical value of the stolen pieces. The jewelry has deep historical roots, tracing back through royal families like the Orléans and to artisans such as François-Régnault Nitot and Paul-Alfred Bapst. The provenance of these items shows a long history of ownership and international movement, with some pieces now held in institutions like the Smithsonian. The incident has sparked global concern over the security of cultural heritage.
